http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Dance Curriculum Standards for 1st grade.
Elements and Skills - Students will identify and demonstrate movement elements and skills in performing dance.
Demonstrate non-locomotor movements such as bend, twist, stretch, and swing.
Demonstrate eight basic locomotor movements (walk, run, hop, jump, leap, gallop, slide and skip) traveling forward, backward, sideward, diagonally, and turning.
Explore movement in personal and general space.
Explore personal space (far-reach, mid-reach and near-reach).
Create a variety of body shapes (straight, angular, curved, twisted) at low, middle and high levels.
Demonstrate movements in straight and curved pathways.
Identify and move individual body parts.
Demonstrate kinesthetic awareness in stillness and movement.
Explore the qualities of energy through movement (smooth, sharp, free, bound, strong, light, vibratory and swinging).
Demonstrate moving to a steady beat and explore responding to changes in tempo.
Demonstrate a basic understanding of spatial relationships (body part to body part and individual to individual); i.e., beside, between, over, under, together and apart.
Choreography - Students will understand choreographic principles, processes, and structures.
Use improvisation to explore and invent a sequence showing a beginning, middle, and end.
Demonstrate the following partner skills: copying, leading and following, and mirroring.
Show the ability to respond in movement to stories, poems, artworks and music.
Creativity and Communication - Students will understand dance as a way to create and communicate meaning.
Explain how dance is different from other forms of human movement (such as sports or everyday gestures).
Present one's dance to peers and explain its meaning.
Demonstrate appropriate audience behavior for dance performances.
Criticism - Students will apply and demonstrate critical and creative thinking skills in dance.
Explore multiple solutions to a given movement problem.
Observe dances and identify similarities and differences.
Cultural/Historical - Students will demonstrate and understand dance in various cultures and historical periods.
Demonstrate a folk dance from a culture.
Identify one way in which people have used dance throughout history as a part of a ceremony.
Health - Students will make connections between dance and healthful living.
Identify the basic parts of the skeleton.
Identify healthy practices (such as nutrition and safety) that enhance the ability to dance.
Interdisciplinary Connections - Students will make connections between dance and other disciplines.
Demonstrate how the same idea can be expressed in dance and in one other art form
Explore the connections between dance and a minimum of two other academic disciplines.
